title: 2025 Kona Hei Hei CR First Look – John Watson
content:
Kona just announced the all-new 2025 Hei Hei CR ($5299 complete, $2950 frame) today. Read on for a quick look from John after his first ride on the bike…

Hey, Hei Hei

Kona’s Hei Hei has been with the brand since 1991, when it was first released as a titanium hardtail. Over the past 34 years, it has evolved into the sleek carbon fiber full-suspension you see here today. While the brand currently markets the Hei Hei as a race machine, it’s proven to be an in-demand model for everyday riders, too.

Quick Hits and Updates:

  • $5299 complete, $2950 frame (in bronze gold)
  • 130 mm front and 120 mm rear travel
  • Swinger rear suspension design
  • Nine bottle bosses
  • UDH compatible
  • Full tube-in-tube internal cable routing
  • Sleeker frame lines
  • No.57 Headset
  • Durable PF92 bottom bracket with ISCG tabs for top guide
  • Rear shock lockout can be routed externally

Geometry and Sizing

I’m testing the size XL frame, and immediately, I noticed the bike’s effective top tube length of 671 mm, putting me in a spread-out and comfortable riding position. This is the most important frame sizing metric to look at, as reach doesn’t take into account seat tube angle. As the seat tube gets steeper, it puts you more forward, and as it slackens, it puts you more backward. Reach remains constant.

The 2025 Hei Hei CR features a 66º head tube angle with a variable seat tube angle, slackening down the sizes. The 75.8º seat tube angle is neither too steep nor too slack, offering a more balanced ride quality.

Hei Hei CR Build Spec

What a build spec. This was my first ride on the new SRAM Eagle 90 Transmission and Motive brakes. I like seeing brands building no-nonsense bikes, free of batteries but built to take a beating. The RockShox Pike fork and Deluxe Ultimate shock set up easily, and as you can see from the o-rings, I’m using just the right amount of suspension travel. Not bad for a literal first ride!

Frame Lines

This new Hei Hei CR got sleekened up, with a straighter seat tube for better seat post insertion and a cleaner, more elegant downtube. Overall, the entire ID of the frame is minimal and subtle. Nothing pops out visually as being out of place. The new body language on the chassis is as subtle as the Gloss Bone paint, which almost disappears against my stucco wall.

 

 

Launch Video

In this cheeky twist on the classic film, Kona Factory athlete Hannah Simms finds herself trapped in a ride-day time loop. Fellow Kona rider Georgios Kouzis joins in on the fun…

Expect a longer, in-depth review as I ride this bike throughout the spring and summer months here in the Southern Rockies. Check out more at Kona.
